docs.lead_paragraph: 9:30 P.M. (ABC) BETTER OFF TED This Season 2 premiere finds Veridian Dynamics trying to pair off its employees based on their genetic compatibility in the hope of saving on health insurance bills resulting from imperfectly bred children. Ted and Linda (Jay Harrington and Andrea Anders, right) think it's a lousy idea -- until they meet their matches, Danielle (Virginia Williams) and Greg (Taye Diggs). Meanwhile, Veronica (Portia de Rossi) learns that Lem (Malcolm Barrett) is supposedly the man for her and urges him to make a donation to a sperm bank. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Matt Lauer and Al Roker report live from Kabul, Afghanistan, Tuesday and Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Senate Democrats try to devise a government-run insurance plan, or public option, that can get at least 60 votes, some are looking again at a program that has long tantalized policy makers as a potential model: the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. That is the program that provides insurance coverage to more than eight million federal workers, including members of Congress and their dependents.
docs.abstract: Senate Democrats are again looking at Federal Employees Health Benefits Program as model for public option insurance plan; program provides insurance coverage to more than eight million federal workers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Organized labor is running a commercial urging centrist Democrats to eliminate the Senate's proposed tax on so-called Cadillac health insurance plans. The move comes as Republicans prepare to offer amendments to eliminate the provision, and puts the A.F.L.-C.I.O. at odds with its Democratic allies. The commercial splices together clips of various workers speaking to the camera. ''Taxing our benefits will just make companies cut our health care,'' one says. ''And cost us more,'' another adds.
docs.abstract: AFL-CIO is running commercial urging centrist Democrats to eliminate Senate's proposed tax on so-called Cadillac health insurance plans; move comes as Republicans prepare to offer amendments to eliminate provision, and puts organized labor at odds with Democratic allies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A liberal advocacy group is running a new television advertisement that accuses Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut, of ignoring his constituents' needs by opposing creation of a new government-run health insurance plan, the so-called public option. Mr. Lieberman has voiced staunch opposition to the public option, which many Democrats support and which in different forms is in the health care legislation passed last month by the House and in the bill now being debated on the Senate floor.
docs.abstract: Liberal advocacy group Progressive Change Campaign Committee is running television ad accusing Sen Joseph I Lieberman of ignoring his constituents' needs by opposing government-run health insurance plan; so-called public option will almost certainly be removed from legislation being debated on Senate floor before final vote is taken, in part because of resistance by Lieberman and others to public plan; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An estimated 85 million Americans do not have dental insurance, and cannot afford dental care. One man, however, finds a way to get his new teeth.

headline.main: With a New Smile, ‘Rage’ Fades Away

docs.snippet: An estimated 85 million Americans do not have dental insurance, and cannot afford dental care. One man, however, finds a way to get his new teeth.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Remote Area Medical Volunteer Corps ran a free eight-day medical clinic in August at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., near Los Angeles, hundreds of people slept in their cars overnight, in some cases for several days, to be sure of getting in. Like many of the people who came to the clinic, Michael Bettis, right, was employed but did not have health or dental insurance. Mr. Bettis, now 37, needed dentures, but first he needed 14 teeth pulled, said Dr. Daniel Cheng, who treated him.

headline.main: Free Care, for Those Who Go Without

docs.abstract: Remote Area Medical Volunteer Corps cares for 6,344 people at eight-day free medical clinic in Inglewood, Calif; photos (M)
